text: Solve this problem step by step.
End with 'DONE.' when you have a solution.
Question: In a classroom of 30 students, each student is assigned a number from 1 to 25 (inclusive).
Prove that there must be at least two students who are assigned the same number.

Solution: 
<think>
Okay, so I have this problem where there are 30 students in a classroom, and each student is assigned a unique number from 1 to 25.
I need to prove that at least two students must have the same number.
Hmm, let me think about how to approach this.
First, I remember something about the pigeonhole principle.
I think that's the idea where if you have more items than containers, at least one container must hold more than one item.
So maybe that applies here.
Let me try to recall the exact statement of the pigeonhole principle.
I think it goes like this: If you have more pigeons than pigeonholes, then at least one pigeonhole must contain more than one pigeon.
In mathematical terms, if you have n items and m containers, where n > m, then at least one container will have more than one item.
Applying that to this problem, the students are the pigeons, and the numbers from 1 to 25 are the pigeonholes.
So how many students do we have? There are 30 students.
How many numbers are assigned? From 1 to 25, that's 25 numbers.
So, we have 30 students (pigeons) and 25 numbers (pigeonholes).
Since 30 is greater than 25, by the pigeonhole principle, at least one number must be assigned to more than one student.
That means there must be at least two students with the same number.
Wait, let me make sure I didn't mix up the numbers.
The range is from 1 to 25, inclusive, so that's 25 different numbers.
We have 30 students, so each number can't be assigned to more than one student without overlap.
But since there are more students than numbers, some numbers must be reused.
Is there another way to think about this? Maybe by considering the maximum number of unique assignments possible.
If each number is assigned to only one student, the maximum number of students we can have is 25.
But we have 30 students, which is 5 more than 25.
So those 5 extra students have to share the numbers with someone else, meaning at least two students must share a number.
Another angle: imagine assigning numbers one by one.
The first 25 students can each get a unique number from 1 to 25.
But the 26th student can't get a new number because we've already used all 25.
So the 26th student has to take a number that's already been taken, which means there's a duplicate.
Similarly, the 27th, 28th, 29th, and 30th students also have to share numbers with someone.
So, no matter how you try to assign the numbers, you can't avoid having at least two students with the same number.
I think I've covered this from multiple perspectives, and each time it comes back to the pigeonhole principle.
So, yeah, the proof is straightforward once you recognize it's a pigeonhole problem.

</think>

By the pigeonhole principle, with 30 students and only 25 unique numbers available, at least two students must share the same number.
